sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews now. I'm Tecumbe Silako with your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Destroy the wall that Russia is building. Ukraine's president urges Berlin to cut all its business ties with Moscow in a stinging rebuke to Germany's parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: A search for survivors is underway after a theater in Mariupol was reduced to rubble.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia denies bombing the building where more than a thousand people were sheltering. And we'll examine whether Tehran's release from jail of two British Iranian nationals means an end to its policy of hostage diplomacy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia is building a wall through Europe. That's the message Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has been delivering to Germany's parliament today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Our reporter in Berlin, Jone Kallgren, joins us now from the Bundestag.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Jone, tell us more about what Volodymyr Zelensky has had to say to MPs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, if you were expecting him to come here or, you know, speak to the parliament here via video link and, you know, express his gratitude and say thank you so very much and then kind of leave it at that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Then you were wrong.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He was quite critical of Germany in this speech, critical of the way Germany acted before the war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He said Germany built this wall or at least helped building this wall that is going through Europe by continuing to have financial interests in Russia, by continuing projects like the Nord Stream 2 project, and by continuing this close connection with Vladimir Putin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And then he was critical of the way that Germany has acted after the war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He said, Germany can't see over this wall.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: You don't see us. You don't see what happens in Ukraine at the moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And he said Germany needs to change now. He thanked Germany for the help that they have given the country so far, financial help, arms and so on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: But he was quite clear in saying it's not enough. It's not enough at all at the moment and he was implying that germany needs to go further together with the eu more arms shipments more uh you know sanctions really cutting the flow of gas and oil into germany and other eu countries and he finished it off by once again touching on germany's history saying berlin had a chance to have a an airlift during the blockade of Berlin. We don't get anything like that in Ukraine at the moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, it will be interesting to see what the ripple effects are of that stirring speech he gave to the Bundestag.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Let's talk a bit, Jonah, if we can, about Germany's response to the refugee crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We've seen pictures we've been covering here over the last 24 hours.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Tell us more about Germany's programme and how it plans to welcome itself up to refugees. Well, there's about 10 or 15,000 Ukrainians arriving here in Berlin every day. There's an immense flow and most of them come here. Some then continue to other parts of Germany or in other parts of Europe, But many of them are staying here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And this is becoming a problem for the city of Berlin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: They're saying they're not getting enough support from the rest of Germany to take care of these refugees that are here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: There are now talk of building tent cities, the places where refugees lived during the 2015 Syrian migration crisis are being opened up again, schools, gym halls and so on. So it is becoming a bit of a situation here. But Germany and at least the city of Berlin also say that they will do everything they can to support these people that are coming. And you're seeing that from the people here. One woman today who's living in a two-bedroom flat, she has eight people living with her and two dogs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And that's not uncommon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So the people here of Germany seem very, very keen on helping these Ukrainians in every way that they can.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Jonah Kragun reporting for us there from the Bundestag on Germany's response to the Ukraine crisis. Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Russian shelling continues as efforts to negotiate an end to the fighting go on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: A 35-hour curfew in Kiev ends Thursday morning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: During that period, several apartments were hit on the outskirts of the capital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: A tweet from Ukraine's foreign minister revealing that a theatre in besieged Mariupol has been destroyed has sparked fears for the fate of hundreds taking refuge there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The building, which had been used as a shelter, had the word CHILDREN written in large white letters on the pavement in front of and behind the theatre.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Amid the constant shelling, there are mixed messages emerging from peace negotiations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Talk of a 15-point plan has been described by Ukraine as just the requesting position of the Russian side.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But talk of Ukraine becoming a neutral country appears to be gaining some traction. Â«Neutral status is now being seriously discussed along, of course, with security guarantees.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: That's exactly what President Putin said at one of these news conferences in February.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Any possible options?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Any generally accepted security guarantees for Ukraine and all countries, including Russia, except for the expansion of NATO.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Negotiations are ongoing, negotiations for the sake of Ukraine. My priorities in the negotiations are absolutely clear. The end of the war, security guarantees, sovereignty, restoration of territorial integrity. Pros integrity prospects for a diplomatic breakthrough remain uncertain given the gulf between ukraine's demand for the invading forces to withdraw completely and russia's suspected aim for replacing kiev's westward-looking government with a pro-moscow regime the war in ukraine has upended the lives of everyone here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But some have yet to grasp the reality of what's happening to them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: At the Pavlov Psychiatric Hospital, over 1,000 patients wait for the war to stop.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Many have been transferred from other areas overrun by the conflict, so the facility is overcapacity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And certain medicines, like antidepressants and antipsychotics, are in short supply.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But doctors say they're coping.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: For now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: In our social media, we post lists of what we need, for example nappies, water and things like that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And a lot of proactive volunteer organizations help us, like restaurants, send food even without asking.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Someone sends us bread, a car filled with apples.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Many of the staff members have moved to the hospital with their families so they can stay with their patients 24-7.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Volunteers have also poured in.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It's my colleague.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We raised like 100 people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And today we, you know, the hairs grow up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We clean something.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And this is for me, it's also kind of pray now for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I remember Saint Francis who washed people, eat to people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now I try to pray every part of my body.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The director of the facility is also praying for the past not to repeat itself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Under the sound of air raid sirens, he shows us the grounds of the medical facility where, during the Nazi occupation of Ukraine, hundreds of patients were murdered by German soldiers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Some executed, others gassed in hospital rooms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We spent so much time analysing the First World War, the Second World War, so many moral and ethical messages. We shouldn't let it happen again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We should learn from our experience.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We should become the better version of ourselves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: In my personal opinion, unfortunately, human and humanity in general isn't becoming better.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: better. ANALYS BORZH is in Kyiv for Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The UN's highest court, the International Court of Justice, has ordered Russia to stop its invasion of Ukraine after ruling it had no grounds for launching its invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: You can read more about that decision on our website, euronews.com.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Time for us to take a break. We'll be back in a few moments.
